Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Terrestrial Linkages to Microbial and Metazoan Communities in Coastal Ecosystems of the Beaufort Sea
Award.AbstractNarration:
Coastal ecosystems of the Arctic receive extraordinarily large quantities of terrestrial organic matter through river discharge and shoreline erosion. The fate of this organic matter is of local interest as it relates to biological production in the coastal ocean. It is also of broader interest with respect to global biogeochemical cycling. The prevailing paradigm is that terrestrial organic matter inputs to the Arctic Ocean are highly recalcitrant. However, most studies supporting this paradigm have been conducted during mid- to late- summer. This effort is based on the premise that terrestrial organic matter, in both dissolved and particulate form, provides an important carbon and energy subsidy that supports and maintains heterotrophic activity and food webs in coastal waters during much of the year. The work will focus on a set of 12 field sites along the Alaskan Beaufort Sea coast, in the vicinity of Barter Island and the Inupiaq village of Kaktovik. Comparisons among sites ranging from lagoons to open coastal systems that receive differing amounts of freshwater runoff and also differ markedly in their exchange characteristics with shelf waters will be used to examine linkages between biological communities and organic matter inputs from land. Examining these linkages will help determine how seasonally distinct terrestrial inputs of water and organic matter influence microbial and metazoan communities in coastal waters of the Alaskan Beaufort Sea. Researchers will address this question thorough a seasonally explicit sampling program that includes field trips during the 9-month ice covered period as well as summer. Measurements of water and sediment chemistry, benthic and water column community characteristics, and natural abundance isotopic tracers will be used to evaluate the importance of terrestrial inputs under different hydrologic/hydrographic conditions.

Understanding the fate of terrestrial carbon in arctic coastal waters is especially important now, as the arctic system enters a period of rapid climatic change. Changes in terrestrial organic matter export could influence total production as well as the relative roles of autotrophy and heterotrophy in arctic coastal waters. Such shifts have consequences for local human populations that use coastal food webs for subsistence and for the broad scientific community interested in land-sea coupling. This work focuses on fundamental questions about the fate of terrestrial organic matter in arctic coastal waters that must be answered before we can effectively consider future changes in land-sea coupling in the Arctic.

This collaborative project will support the dissertation research of two graduate students and two post-doctoral associates and also continue a very successful K-12 outreach program, entitled ?Climate Change in the Arctic: An Interactive Program Linking Scientists with K-12 Students? that includes the establishment of a summer field science program for native Kaktovik K-12 students. The Village Council has expressed keen enthusiasm to involve middle school students in hands-on science activities that can be provided in conjunction with teachers from the Kaktovik school district.

Scientific Merit. Estuarine systems are dominant features of the world’s shorelines, and are among the most productive natural habitats in the world. They also serve as sentinel environments that are highly sensitive to human activities in adjoining watersheds. A critical feature of these systems is their dependence on freshwater inflow to maintain gradients in environmental characteristics and in the delivery of nutrients and organic matter that fuel coastal food webs. In the Arctic, climate change is causing increased shoreline erosion and changes in river inputs to the ocean. In order to anticipate how these changes may impact coastal ecosystems, it is essential that we understand the key sources of nutrients and organic matter supporting coastal food webs in the Arctic.

Research supported by ARC-1023582 and ARC-1023465 aimed to improve fundamental understanding of the resources that support coastal food webs in the Arctic. Particular emphasis was placed on seasonal variations in nutrients and organic matter available to biota living within lagoon ecosystems, and the relative importance of contributions from the land and sea to these ecosystems. Field sites for this project were established along the eastern Alaska Beaufort Sea coast during August 2011. These sites included lagoons and open water areas between the Hulahula River delta and Demarcation Bay (Figure 1). Summer work continued in 2012 and 2013. In addition, field work was conducted during April (ice covered) and June (ice break-up) of 2012 and 2013 at a subset of sites.

Results from the field efforts have yielded exciting new insights about seasonality in Arctic coastal ecosystems and the potential importance of land-derived inputs as resources supporting food webs in near-shore waters. Lagoon ecosystems, in particular, stand out as hotspots where food webs are enhanced by terrestrial materials through direct consumption by detritivores and through indirect enhancement of algal growth via bacterial recycling of organic nutrients. Recycled nutrients build up under the ice during the winter, but are rapidly depleted during the ice break-up period and remain low throughout the summer. In contrast, organic matter concentrations peak strongly during the spring in association with high terrestrial runoff. Project results also indicate that communities of bacteria in lagoon waters are compositionally distinct among seasons and are strongly linked to variability in terrestrial inputs. This project has produced >15 presentations at national and international meetings and two publications to date (Nolan et al., 2011; Dunton et al., 2012). A third paper (Connelly et al., under review) is in the late stages of the review/revision process and should be in press by the end of 2014. Project data are publicly available through the Advanced Cooperative Arctic Data and Information Service (ACADIS) web site at www.aoncadis.org/project/microbial_and_metazoan.html.

Broader Impacts. In addition to research, ARC-1023582 and ARC-1023465 supported a Summer Science Program for youth living in the village of Kaktovik. The program involved 70 participants ranging from 3 to 18 years old over four consecutive summers (2011-2014). Given that there are approximately 250 residents in Kaktovik, this represents a significant proportion of the local population. The program also brought three K-12 teachers from Texas to Kaktovik. While this was integral to the success of the program, it also provided the teachers with new perspectives to share with their students back home. The Summer Science Program was run for one week during each year.
